trans-unit.source: ms.ContentId: 347fa279-d588-4094-90ec-8c2fc241f5b6 title: Manage Windows Server Containers with Docker
trans-unit.target: ms.ContentId: 347fa279-d588-4094-90ec-8c2fc241f5b6 title: Manage Windows Server Containers with Docker

trans-unit.source: Quick Start: Windows Server Containers and Docker
trans-unit.target: Quick Start: Windows Server Containers and Docker

trans-unit.source: This article will walk through the fundamentals of managing windows Server Containers with Docker.
trans-unit.target: This article will walk through the fundamentals of managing windows Server Containers with Docker.

trans-unit.source: Items covered will include creating Windows Server Containers and Windows Server Container Images, removing Windows Server Containers and Container Images and finally deploying an application into a Windows Server Container.
trans-unit.target: Items covered will include creating Windows Server Containers and Windows Server Container Images, removing Windows Server Containers and Container Images and finally deploying an application into a Windows Server Container.

trans-unit.source: The lessons learned in this walkthrough should enable you to begin exploring deployment and management of Windows Server Containers using Docker.
trans-unit.target: The lessons learned in this walkthrough should enable you to begin exploring deployment and management of Windows Server Containers using Docker.

trans-unit.source: Have questions?
trans-unit.target: Have questions?

trans-unit.source: Ask them on the
trans-unit.target: Ask them on the

trans-unit.source: Windows Containers forum
trans-unit.target: Windows Containers forum

trans-unit.source: Note:
trans-unit.target: Note:

trans-unit.source: Windows Containers created with PowerShell can not currently be managed with Docker and visa versa.
trans-unit.target: Windows Containers created with PowerShell can not currently be managed with Docker and visa versa.

trans-unit.source: To create containers with PowerShell, see
trans-unit.target: To create containers with PowerShell, see

trans-unit.source: Quick Start: Windows Server Containers and PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Quick Start: Windows Server Containers and PowerShell

trans-unit.source: If you want to know more,
trans-unit.target: If you want to know more,

trans-unit.source: read the FAQ
trans-unit.target: read the FAQ

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: In order to complete this walkthrough the following items need to be in place.
trans-unit.target: In order to complete this walkthrough the following items need to be in place.

trans-unit.source: Windows Server 2016 TP3 or later configured with the Windows Server Container Feature.
trans-unit.target: Windows Server 2016 TP3 or later configured with the Windows Server Container Feature.

trans-unit.source: If you have completed the setup guide, this is the VM that was created in Azure or Hyper-V.
trans-unit.target: If you have completed the setup guide, this is the VM that was created in Azure or Hyper-V.

trans-unit.source: This system must be connected to a network and able to access the internet.
trans-unit.target: This system must be connected to a network and able to access the internet.

trans-unit.source: If you need to configure the container feature, see the following guides:
trans-unit.target: If you need to configure the container feature, see the following guides:

trans-unit.source: Container Setup in Azure
trans-unit.target: Container Setup in Azure

trans-unit.source: or
trans-unit.target: or

trans-unit.source: Container Setup in Hyper-V
trans-unit.target: Container Setup in Hyper-V

trans-unit.source: Basic Container Management with Docker
trans-unit.target: Basic Container Management with Docker

trans-unit.source: This first example will walk through the basics of creating and removing Windows Server Containers and Windows Server Container Images with Docker.
trans-unit.target: This first example will walk through the basics of creating and removing Windows Server Containers and Windows Server Container Images with Docker.

trans-unit.source: To begin the walk through, log into your Windows Server Container Host System, you will see a Windows command prompt.
trans-unit.target: To begin the walk through, log into your Windows Server Container Host System, you will see a Windows command prompt.

trans-unit.source: Start a PowerShell session by typing
trans-unit.target: Start a PowerShell session by typing

trans-unit.source: You will know that you are in a PowerShell session when the prompt changes from
trans-unit.target: You will know that you are in a PowerShell session when the prompt changes from

trans-unit.source: to
trans-unit.target: to

trans-unit.source: This quick start will be focused on Docker commands however some steps such as managing firewall rules and copying files will be run with PowerShell commands.
trans-unit.target: This quick start will be focused on Docker commands however some steps such as managing firewall rules and copying files will be run with PowerShell commands.

trans-unit.source: Work through this walkthrough from a PowerShell session.
trans-unit.target: Work through this walkthrough from a PowerShell session.

trans-unit.source: Next make sure that your system has a valid IP Address using
trans-unit.target: Next make sure that your system has a valid IP Address using

trans-unit.source: and take note of this address for later use.
trans-unit.target: and take note of this address for later use.

trans-unit.source: If you are working from an Azure VM instead of using
trans-unit.target: If you are working from an Azure VM instead of using

trans-unit.source: you will need to get the public IP address of the Azure Virtual Machine.
trans-unit.target: you will need to get the public IP address of the Azure Virtual Machine.

trans-unit.source: Step 1 - Create a New Container
trans-unit.target: Step 1 - Create a New Container

trans-unit.source: Before creating a Windows Server Container with Docker you will need the name or ID of an exsisitng Windows Server Container image.
trans-unit.target: Before creating a Windows Server Container with Docker you will need the name or ID of an exsisitng Windows Server Container image.

trans-unit.source: To see all images loaded on the container host use the
trans-unit.target: To see all images loaded on the container host use the

trans-unit.source: command.
trans-unit.target: command.

trans-unit.source: ``` PowerShell docker images
trans-unit.target: ``` PowerShell docker images

trans-unit.source: REPOSITORY TAG IMAGE ID CREATED VIRTUAL SIZE windowsservercore latest 9eca9231f4d4 30 hours ago 9.613 GB windowsservercore 10.0.10254.0 9eca9231f4d4 30 hours ago 9.613 GB
trans-unit.target: REPOSITORY TAG IMAGE ID CREATED VIRTUAL SIZE windowsservercore latest 9eca9231f4d4 30 hours ago 9.613 GB windowsservercore 10.0.10254.0 9eca9231f4d4 30 hours ago 9.613 GB

trans-unit.source: When the command completes you will be working in a console session on the container.
trans-unit.target: When the command completes you will be working in a console session on the container.

trans-unit.source: Working in a container is almost identical to working with Windows installed on a virtual or physical machine.
trans-unit.target: Working in a container is almost identical to working with Windows installed on a virtual or physical machine.

trans-unit.source: You can run commands such as
trans-unit.target: You can run commands such as

trans-unit.source: to return the IP address of the container,
trans-unit.target: to return the IP address of the container,

trans-unit.source: to create a new directory, or
trans-unit.target: to create a new directory, or

trans-unit.source: to start a PowerShell session.
trans-unit.target: to start a PowerShell session.

trans-unit.source: Go ahead and make a change to the container such as creating a file or folder.
trans-unit.target: Go ahead and make a change to the container such as creating a file or folder.

trans-unit.source: For example, the following command will create a file which contains network configuration data about the container.
trans-unit.target: For example, the following command will create a file which contains network configuration data about the container.

trans-unit.source: ``` PowerShell ipconfig > c:\ipconfig.txt
trans-unit.target: ``` PowerShell ipconfig > c:\ipconfig.txt

trans-unit.source: Now that the container has been modified, run the following to stop the console session placing you back in the console session of the container host.
trans-unit.target: Now that the container has been modified, run the following to stop the console session placing you back in the console session of the container host.

trans-unit.source: ``` PowerShell exit
trans-unit.target: ``` PowerShell exit

trans-unit.source: Step 2 - Create a New Container Image
trans-unit.target: Step 2 - Create a New Container Image

trans-unit.source: An image can now be made from this container.
trans-unit.target: An image can now be made from this container.

trans-unit.source: This image will behave like a snapshot of the container and can be re-deployed many times.
trans-unit.target: This image will behave like a snapshot of the container and can be re-deployed many times.

trans-unit.source: To create a new image run the following.
trans-unit.target: To create a new image run the following.

trans-unit.source: This command instructs the Docker engine to create a new image named 'newcontainerimage' that will include all changes made to the 'deckerdemo' container.
trans-unit.target: This command instructs the Docker engine to create a new image named 'newcontainerimage' that will include all changes made to the 'deckerdemo' container.

trans-unit.source: ``` PowerShell docker commit dockerdemo newcontainerimage
trans-unit.target: ``` PowerShell docker commit dockerdemo newcontainerimage

trans-unit.source: Step 3 - Create New Container From Image
trans-unit.target: Step 3 - Create New Container From Image

trans-unit.source: Now that you have a custom container image, deploy a new container named 'newcontainer' from 'newcontainerimage' and open an interactive shell session with the container.
trans-unit.target: Now that you have a custom container image, deploy a new container named 'newcontainer' from 'newcontainerimage' and open an interactive shell session with the container.

trans-unit.source: ``` PowerShell docker run –it --name newcontainer newcontainerimage cmd
trans-unit.target: ``` PowerShell docker run –it --name newcontainer newcontainerimage cmd

trans-unit.source: This exercise has shown that an image taken from a modified container will include all modifications.
trans-unit.target: This exercise has shown that an image taken from a modified container will include all modifications.

trans-unit.source: While the example here was a simple file modification, the same would apply if you were to install software into the container such as a web server.
trans-unit.target: While the example here was a simple file modification, the same would apply if you were to install software into the container such as a web server.

trans-unit.source: Using these methods, custom images can be created that will deploy application ready containers.
trans-unit.target: Using these methods, custom images can be created that will deploy application ready containers.

trans-unit.source: Step 4 - Remove Containers and Images
trans-unit.target: Step 4 - Remove Containers and Images

trans-unit.source: To remove a container after it is no longer needed use the
trans-unit.target: To remove a container after it is no longer needed use the

trans-unit.source: command.
trans-unit.target: command.

trans-unit.source: The following command will remove the container name 'newcontainer'.
trans-unit.target: The following command will remove the container name 'newcontainer'.

trans-unit.source: ``` PowerShell docker rm newcontainer
trans-unit.target: ``` PowerShell docker rm newcontainer

trans-unit.source: Host a Web Server in a Container
trans-unit.target: Host a Web Server in a Container

trans-unit.source: This next example will demonstrate a more practical use case for Windows Server Containers.
trans-unit.target: This next example will demonstrate a more practical use case for Windows Server Containers.

trans-unit.source: The steps included in this exercise will guide you through creating a web server container image that can be used for deploying web applications hosted inside of a Windows Server Container.
trans-unit.target: The steps included in this exercise will guide you through creating a web server container image that can be used for deploying web applications hosted inside of a Windows Server Container.

trans-unit.source: Step 1 - Download Web Server Software
trans-unit.target: Step 1 - Download Web Server Software

trans-unit.source: Before creating a container image the web server software will need to be downloaded and staged on the container host.
trans-unit.target: Before creating a container image the web server software will need to be downloaded and staged on the container host.

trans-unit.source: We will be using the nginx for Windows software for this example.
trans-unit.target: We will be using the nginx for Windows software for this example.

trans-unit.source: Note
trans-unit.target: Note

trans-unit.source: that this step will require the container host to be connected to the internet.
trans-unit.target: that this step will require the container host to be connected to the internet.

trans-unit.source: If this step produces a connectivity or name resolution error check the network configuration of the container host.
trans-unit.target: If this step produces a connectivity or name resolution error check the network configuration of the container host.

trans-unit.source: Run the following command on the container host to create the directory structure that will be used for this example.
trans-unit.target: Run the following command on the container host to create the directory structure that will be used for this example.

trans-unit.source: ``` PowerShell mkdir c:\build\nginx\source
trans-unit.target: ``` PowerShell mkdir c:\build\nginx\source

trans-unit.source: Finally the following command will extract the nginx software to 'C:\build\nginx\source'.
trans-unit.target: Finally the following command will extract the nginx software to 'C:\build\nginx\source'.

trans-unit.source: ``` PowerShell Expand-Archive -Path C:\nginx-1.9.3.zip -DestinationPath C:\build\nginx\source -Force
trans-unit.target: ``` PowerShell Expand-Archive -Path C:\nginx-1.9.3.zip -DestinationPath C:\build\nginx\source -Force

trans-unit.source: Open the dockerfile with notepad.
trans-unit.target: Open the dockerfile with notepad.

trans-unit.source: Copy and paste the following text into notepad, save the file and close notepad.
trans-unit.target: Copy and paste the following text into notepad, save the file and close notepad.

trans-unit.source: ``` PowerShell FROM windowsservercore LABEL Description="nginx For Windows" Vendor="nginx" Version="1.9.3" ADD source /nginx
trans-unit.target: ``` PowerShell FROM windowsservercore LABEL Description="nginx For Windows" Vendor="nginx" Version="1.9.3" ADD source /nginx

trans-unit.source: This command instructs the docker engine to use the dockerfile located at
trans-unit.target: This command instructs the docker engine to use the dockerfile located at

trans-unit.source: to create an image named 'nginx_windows'.
trans-unit.target: to create an image named 'nginx_windows'.

trans-unit.source: The output will look similar to this:
trans-unit.target: The output will look similar to this:

trans-unit.source: When completed, take a look at the images on the host using the
trans-unit.target: When completed, take a look at the images on the host using the

trans-unit.source: command.
trans-unit.target: command.

trans-unit.source: You should see a new image named 'nginx_windows'.
trans-unit.target: You should see a new image named 'nginx_windows'.

trans-unit.source: ``` PowerShell docker images
trans-unit.target: ``` PowerShell docker images

trans-unit.source: REPOSITORY TAG IMAGE ID CREATED VIRTUAL SIZE
trans-unit.target: REPOSITORY TAG IMAGE ID CREATED VIRTUAL SIZE

trans-unit.source: nginx_windows latest d792268338d0 5 seconds ago 9.613 GB windowsservercore 10.0.10254.0 9eca9231f4d4 35 hours ago 9.613 GB windowsservercore latest 9eca9231f4d4 35 hours ago 9.613 GB
trans-unit.target: nginx_windows latest d792268338d0 5 seconds ago 9.613 GB windowsservercore 10.0.10254.0 9eca9231f4d4 35 hours ago 9.613 GB windowsservercore latest 9eca9231f4d4 35 hours ago 9.613 GB

trans-unit.source: Next if you are working from Azure and have not already created a Virtual Machine endpoint you will need to create one now.
trans-unit.target: Next if you are working from Azure and have not already created a Virtual Machine endpoint you will need to create one now.

trans-unit.source: For more information on Azure VM Endpoints see this article:
trans-unit.target: For more information on Azure VM Endpoints see this article:

trans-unit.source: Set up Azure VM Endpoints
trans-unit.target: Set up Azure VM Endpoints

trans-unit.source: Step 4 - Deploy Web Server Ready Container
trans-unit.target: Step 4 - Deploy Web Server Ready Container

trans-unit.source: To deploy a Windows Server Container based off of the 'nginx_windows' container run the following command.
trans-unit.target: To deploy a Windows Server Container based off of the 'nginx_windows' container run the following command.

trans-unit.source: This will create a new container named 'nginxcontainer' and start an console session on the container.
trans-unit.target: This will create a new container named 'nginxcontainer' and start an console session on the container.

trans-unit.source: The –p 80:80 portion of this command creates a port mapping between port 80 on the host to port 80 on the container.
trans-unit.target: The –p 80:80 portion of this command creates a port mapping between port 80 on the host to port 80 on the container.

trans-unit.source: ``` powershell docker run -it --name nginxcontainer -p 80:80 nginx_windows cmd
trans-unit.target: ``` powershell docker run -it --name nginxcontainer -p 80:80 nginx_windows cmd

trans-unit.source: Start the nginx web server.
trans-unit.target: Start the nginx web server.

trans-unit.source: ``` powershell start nginx
trans-unit.target: ``` powershell start nginx

trans-unit.source: After the website has been updated, navigate back to
trans-unit.target: After the website has been updated, navigate back to

trans-unit.target: Note:

trans-unit.source: If you would like to change the Docker Daemon settings (such as to change the port it listens to, to connect to a container remotely), you will need to edit the file "C:\ProgramData\docker\runDockerDaemon.cmd" in the container, and then you will need to restart the service with PowerShell, using
trans-unit.target: If you would like to change the Docker Daemon settings (such as to change the port it listens to, to connect to a container remotely), you will need to edit the file "C:\ProgramData\docker\runDockerDaemon.cmd" in the container, and then you will need to restart the service with PowerShell, using
